sections.title: Introduction: Blood-Brain Barrier and Nanoparticle Delivery Challenges
sections.tldr: The blood-brain barrier (BBB) presents a significant challenge for drug delivery to the central nervous system due to its tight junctions that restrict substance exchange. Surface modifications of nanoparticles offer promising strategies to enhance BBB penetration through various mechanisms including receptor-mediated transcytosis, size optimization, and charge alterations. (11 sources)
sections.text:
The blood-brain barrier (BBB) represents one of the most formidable obstacles in delivering therapeutics to the central nervous system (CNS). Unlike blood capillaries elsewhere in the body, the BBB is characterized by tight junctions between endothelial cells that line cerebral microvessels, creating a highly selective barrier that restricts the exchange of substances between the blood and nervous tissue <Paper corpusId="174798792" paperTitle="(Khongkow et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="20863171" paperTitle="(Wilhelm et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This protective mechanism, while essential for normal brain function, significantly limits the effectiveness of conventional drug delivery approaches targeting neurological conditions.

Nanotechnology has emerged as a promising solution to overcome the BBB challenge, with various nanoparticle platforms including polymeric nanoparticles, liposomes, hydrogels, and dendrimers showing potential for enhanced brain delivery <Paper corpusId="229241129" paperTitle="(Liao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="277084247" paperTitle="(El-Tanani et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. The effectiveness of nanoparticles in crossing the BBB is influenced by several key parameters: (i) size, with generally an inverse correlation between nanoparticle size and BBB penetration; (ii) shape, which affects body distribution and cellular uptake; (iii) the type of targeting ligands attached; and (iv) surface charge or zeta potential <Paper corpusId="214787055" paperTitle="(Saint-Pol et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

Surface modification has proven to be a particularly effective strategy for enhancing nanoparticle transport across the BBB <Paper corpusId="270043887" paperTitle="(Cai et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These modifications can take various forms, including physical coating with surfactants, chemical functionalization with specific ligands, alteration of surface charge, and optimization of size <Paper corpusId="219332656" paperTitle="(Lombardo et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="267137806" paperTitle="(Selvin, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. For instance, coating nanoparticles with biopolymers like polyethylene glycol (PEG) can increase systemic circulation time by reducing interactions that lead to clearance and opsonization <Paper corpusId="229241129" paperTitle="(Liao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="277910377" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

One of the most frequently employed strategies is receptor-mediated transcytosis (RMT), which exploits specific receptors expressed on the BBB. Gold nanoparticles tagged with transferrin or antibodies against transferrin receptors have successfully achieved brain internalization through this mechanism <Paper corpusId="174798792" paperTitle="(Khongkow et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="21284359" paperTitle="(Cabezon et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach has shown that nanoparticles can internalize individually in vesicles through a TfR-mediated and clathrin-dependent process, although optimization is still needed for efficient drug delivery as many particles end up in endosomes or lysosomes rather than crossing completely into the brain parenchyma <Paper corpusId="21284359" paperTitle="(Cabezon et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>.

The physical characteristics of nanoparticles significantly influence their BBB transport capabilities. Studies using three-dimensional human BBB microfluidic models have demonstrated that parameters such as size, shape, and flexibility impact both nanoparticle association with the brain endothelium and their transport across the BBB <Paper corpusId="229241129" paperTitle="(Liao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="213670058" paperTitle="(Nowak et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Interestingly, BBB transport exhibits a nonmonotonic dependence on size, with medium-sized particles (around 200 nm) sometimes showing better penetration than both smaller and larger ones <Paper corpusId="213670058" paperTitle="(Nowak et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: In vitro models of the blood-brain barrier for the study of drug delivery to the brain.

snippets: The most important obstacle to the drug delivery into the brain is the presence of the blood-brain barrier, which limits the traffic of substances between the blood and the nervous tissue. Therefore, adequate in vitro models need to be developed in order to characterize the penetration properties of drug candidates into the central nervous system. This review article summarizes the presently used and the most promising in vitro BBB models based on the culture of brain endothelial cells. Robust models can be obtained using primary porcine brain endothelial cells and rodent coculture models, which have low paracellular permeability and express functional efflux transporters, showing good correlation of drug penetration data with in vivo results. Models mimicking the in vivo anatomophysiological complexity of the BBB are also available, including triple coculture (culture of brain endothelial cells in the presence of pericytes and astrocytes), dynamic, and microfluidic models; however, these are not suitable for rapid, high throughput studies. Potent human cell lines would be needed for easily available and reproducible models which avoid interspecies differences.

paper.title: Trafficking of Gold Nanoparticles Coated with the 8D3 Anti-Transferrin Receptor Antibody at the Mouse Blood-Brain Barrier.

snippets: Receptor-mediated transcytosis has been widely studied as a possible strategy to transport neurotherapeutics across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Monoclonal antibodies directed against the transferrin receptor (TfR) have been proposed as potential carrier candidates. A better understanding of the mechanisms involved in their cellular uptake and intracellular trafficking is required and could critically contribute to the improvement of delivery methods. Accordingly, we studied here the trafficking of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) coated with the 8D3 anti-transferrin receptor antibody at the mouse BBB. 8D3-AuNPs were intravenously administered to mice and allowed to recirculate for a range of times, from 10 min to 24 h, before brain extraction and analysis by transmission electron microscope techniques. Our results indicated a TfR-mediated and clathrin-dependent internalization process by which 8D3-AuNPs internalize individually in vesicles. These vesicles then follow at least two different routes. On one hand, most vesicles enter intracellular processes of vesicular fusion and rearrangement in which the AuNPs end up accumulating in late endosomes, multivesicular bodies or lysosomes, which present a high AuNP content. On the other hand, a small percentage of the vesicles follow a different route in which they fuse with the abluminal membrane and open to the basal membrane. In these cases, the 8D3-AuNPs remain attached to the abluminal membrane, which suggests an endosomal escape, but not dissociation from TfR. Altogether, although receptor-mediated transport continues to be one of the most promising strategies to overcome the BBB, different optimization approaches need to be developed for efficient drug delivery.

paper.title: Size, shape, and flexibility influence nanoparticle transport across brain endothelium under flow

snippets: Abstract Nanoparticle‐based therapeutic formulations are being increasingly explored for the treatment of various ailments. Despite numerous advances, the success of nanoparticle‐based technologies in treating brain diseases has been limited. Translational hurdles of nanoparticle therapies are attributed primarily to their limited ability to cross the blood–brain barrier (BBB), which is one of the body's most exclusive barriers. Several efforts have been focused on developing affinity‐based agents and using them to increase nanoparticle accumulation at the brain endothelium. Very little is known about the role of fundamental physical parameters of nanoparticles such as size, shape, and flexibility in determining their interactions with and penetration across the BBB. Using a three‐dimensional human BBB microfluidic model (μHuB), we investigate the impact of these physical parameters on nanoparticle penetration across the BBB. To gain insights into the dependence of transport on nanoparticle properties, two separate parameters were measured: the number of nanoparticles that fully cross the BBB and the number that remain associated with the endothelium. Association of nanoparticles with the brain endothelium was substantially impacted by their physical characteristics. Hard particles associate more with the endothelium compared to soft particles, as do small particles compared to large particles, and spherical particles compared to rod‐shaped particles. Transport across the BBB also exhibited a dependence on nanoparticle properties. A nonmonotonic dependence on size was observed, where 200 nm particles exhibited higher BBB transport compared to 100 and 500 nm spheres. Rod‐shaped particles exhibited higher BBB transport when normalized by endothelial association and soft particles exhibited comparable transport to hard particles when normalized by endothelial association. Tuning nanoparticles' physical parameters could potentially enhance their ability to cross the BBB for therapeutic applications.

sections.title: Surfactant-Based Surface Modifications
sections.tldr: Surfactant coatings, particularly polysorbate 80 and poloxamer 188, significantly enhance nanoparticle transport across the blood-brain barrier by facilitating apolipoprotein adsorption that enables receptor-mediated transcytosis. These modifications have demonstrated substantial improvements in brain drug delivery, with polysorbate 80-coated nanoparticles showing up to 20-fold enhanced BBB penetration compared to uncoated particles. (9 sources)
sections.text:
Surfactant coatings represent one of the most effective approaches for enhancing nanoparticle transport across the blood-brain barrier. Polysorbate 80 (Tween 80) has emerged as a particularly valuable surfactant for this purpose, with numerous studies demonstrating its ability to dramatically improve brain-specific delivery of therapeutic agents. When applied to polybutylcyanoacrylate (PBCA) nanoparticles, polysorbate 80 coating has enabled successful brain delivery of various drugs including dalargin, tubocurarine, and doxorubicin that otherwise cannot cross the BBB effectively <Paper corpusId="265073990" paperTitle="(Niazi, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

The mechanism behind polysorbate 80's effectiveness involves its ability to adsorb plasma apolipoproteins, particularly apolipoprotein E (ApoE), onto the nanoparticle surface. This modification essentially allows the nanoparticles to mimic low-density lipoproteins (LDL), enabling recognition by LDL receptors expressed on brain endothelial cells and subsequent transport across the BBB via receptor-mediated endocytosis <Paper corpusId="268928188" paperTitle="(Narsinh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10445103" paperTitle="(Kanwar et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have reported remarkable improvements in BBB penetration, with Kreuter finding that polysorbate 80-coated nanoparticles transported drugs through the barrier with a 20-fold improvement over uncoated nanoparticles <Paper corpusId="5143982" paperTitle="(Parratt et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

Another surfactant demonstrating significant BBB-crossing enhancement is poloxamer 188 (F68), which has been shown to increase the delivery of drug-loaded PBCA and poly(lactide-co-glycolide) (PLGA) nanoparticles to the brain in rats <Paper corpusId="10445103" paperTitle="(Kanwar et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. Like polysorbate 80, poloxamer 188 facilitates ApoE adsorption onto polymeric nanoparticles, enabling recognition by LDL receptors on brain endothelial cells <Paper corpusId="225464702" paperTitle="(Hartl et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The effectiveness of surfactant-based modifications has been demonstrated in multiple studies. Lamptey and colleagues reported that surface functionalization of PLGA nanoparticles with polysorbate 80 increased brain concentration of the neuroprotective agent Bacoside-A to 23.94 ± 1.74 µg/g tissue, over ten times higher than the concentration achieved with pure drug solution <Paper corpusId="256288184" paperTitle="(Lamptey et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. Similarly, polysorbate 80-coated doxorubicin-loaded and gemcitabine-loaded PBCA nanoparticles showed enhanced brain specificity and efficacy compared to unmodified nanoparticles <Paper corpusId="10445103" paperTitle="(Kanwar et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

Beyond facilitating receptor-mediated transcytosis, surfactant coatings appear to enhance BBB permeation through additional mechanisms. They may inhibit the efflux action of P-glycoprotein and solubilize cell membrane lipids of brain endothelial cells to facilitate entry <Paper corpusId="10445103" paperTitle="(Kanwar et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="52036623" paperTitle="(Carvalho et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. Some researchers have also suggested that surfactant coatings help bind nanoparticles to capillary linings, creating concentration gradients that facilitate diffusion or induce phagocytosis processes in epithelial cells <Paper corpusId="5143982" paperTitle="(Parratt et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="30272015" paperTitle="(Schroeder et al., 1998)" isShortName></Paper>.

Other surfactants that have shown promise include polysorbate 85, dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline, and cholesterol-based lipid bilayers. Studies have found that charged nanoparticles coated with dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline and cholesterol-based lipid bilayer showed three to four times increased penetration across the BBB <Paper corpusId="56080588" paperTitle="(Kiani et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, polysorbate 85-stabilized nanoparticles have demonstrated the ability to induce analgesia after intravenous application even without additional coating <Paper corpusId="5143982" paperTitle="(Parratt et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="30272015" paperTitle="(Schroeder et al., 1998)" isShortName></Paper>.

sections.text:
Polymer-based surface modifications represent a cornerstone strategy for enhancing nanoparticle transport across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Among these, PEGylation—the process of covalent or non-covalent attachment of polyethylene glycol (PEG) chains to nanoparticle surfaces—has emerged as the most extensively employed approach <Paper corpusId="199545358" paperTitle="(Tiwari et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="277910377" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. The primary advantage of PEGylation is its ability to significantly increase nanoparticles' systemic circulation time by reducing interactions that lead to clearance and opsonization <Paper corpusId="229241129" paperTitle="(Liao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This extended circulation provides nanoparticles with more opportunities to interact with and potentially cross the BBB.

Multiple studies have reported that PEGylated nanoparticles cross the BBB more efficiently than nanoparticles with various other surface modifications, although the precise mechanism behind this enhanced penetration remains not fully elucidated <Paper corpusId="227044620" paperTitle="(Vani et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. The efficacy of PEGylation appears to be related to its ability to enhance stability in biological environments, improve pharmacokinetics, and protect the encapsulated drug from degradation <Paper corpusId="210827082" paperTitle="(Mahmoud et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="10196151" paperTitle="(Meyers et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, PEGylation can improve drug specificity and increase the solubility of hydrophobic drugs, making it a versatile modification approach <Paper corpusId="277910377" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

An important aspect of PEGylation is the ability to control the coating density. Research has shown that densely PEG-coated nanoparticles up to 114 nm in size are capable of both diffusive and convective transport through the brain parenchyma <Paper corpusId="229241129" paperTitle="(Liao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This represents a significant advantage for therapeutic delivery beyond the BBB, as it allows nanoparticles to penetrate deeper into brain tissue after crossing the endothelial barrier.

Beyond PEGylation, researchers are exploring combinations of polymer modifications with other targeting strategies. For instance, PEGylated nanoparticles can be further decorated with targeting ligands like transferrin to enhance specificity to target sites in the brain <Paper corpusId="277910377" paperTitle="(Jiang et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. This combinatorial approach leverages both the enhanced circulation provided by the polymer coating and the targeting capability of the attached ligands.

The physical characteristics of polymer-coated nanoparticles, including size, shape, and flexibility, also significantly influence their BBB penetration capabilities. Studies using three-dimensional human BBB microfluidic models have demonstrated that these parameters impact both nanoparticle association with the brain endothelium and their transport across the BBB <Paper corpusId="229241129" paperTitle="(Liao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="213670058" paperTitle="(Nowak et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Interestingly, a nonmonotonic dependence on size has been observed, where medium-sized particles (around 200 nm) exhibited higher BBB transport compared to both smaller (100 nm) and larger (500 nm) spheres <Paper corpusId="213670058" paperTitle="(Nowak et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

Polymer surface modifications are also being explored in conjunction with stimuli-responsive features, creating "smart" nanoparticles that can release drugs in response to specific stimuli such as pH changes or the presence of reactive oxygen species <Paper corpusId="278496075" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. These advanced functionalization approaches, which include both PEGylation and ligand conjugation, have shown promise for enhancing BBB transport and improving drug bioavailability <Paper corpusId="278899041" paperTitle="(Narayan et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, polymer-modified nanoparticles can be designed to work synergistically with other BBB-crossing strategies, such as those using cell-penetrating peptides, to further improve delivery efficiency to brain tissues <Paper corpusId="272783721" paperTitle="(Strika et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="201204343" paperTitle="(Alexander et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Size, shape, and flexibility influence nanoparticle transport across brain endothelium under flow

snippets: Abstract Nanoparticle‐based therapeutic formulations are being increasingly explored for the treatment of various ailments. Despite numerous advances, the success of nanoparticle‐based technologies in treating brain diseases has been limited. Translational hurdles of nanoparticle therapies are attributed primarily to their limited ability to cross the blood–brain barrier (BBB), which is one of the body's most exclusive barriers. Several efforts have been focused on developing affinity‐based agents and using them to increase nanoparticle accumulation at the brain endothelium. Very little is known about the role of fundamental physical parameters of nanoparticles such as size, shape, and flexibility in determining their interactions with and penetration across the BBB. Using a three‐dimensional human BBB microfluidic model (μHuB), we investigate the impact of these physical parameters on nanoparticle penetration across the BBB. To gain insights into the dependence of transport on nanoparticle properties, two separate parameters were measured: the number of nanoparticles that fully cross the BBB and the number that remain associated with the endothelium. Association of nanoparticles with the brain endothelium was substantially impacted by their physical characteristics. Hard particles associate more with the endothelium compared to soft particles, as do small particles compared to large particles, and spherical particles compared to rod‐shaped particles. Transport across the BBB also exhibited a dependence on nanoparticle properties. A nonmonotonic dependence on size was observed, where 200 nm particles exhibited higher BBB transport compared to 100 and 500 nm spheres. Rod‐shaped particles exhibited higher BBB transport when normalized by endothelial association and soft particles exhibited comparable transport to hard particles when normalized by endothelial association. Tuning nanoparticles' physical parameters could potentially enhance their ability to cross the BBB for therapeutic applications.

paper.title: Recent expansions of novel strategies towards the drug targeting into the brain

snippets: Abstract The treatment of central nervous system (CNS) disorders always remains a challenge for the researchers. The presence of various physiological barriers, primarily the blood–brain barrier (BBB) limits the accessibility of the brain and hinders the efficacy of various drug therapies. Hence, drug targeting to the brain, particularly to the diseased cells by circumventing the physiological barriers is essential to develop a promising therapy for the treatment of brain disorders. Presently, the investigations emphasize the role of different nanocarrier systems or surface modified target specific novel carrier system to improve the efficiency and reduce the side effects of the brain therapeutics. Such approaches supposed to circumvent the BBB or have the ability to cross the barrier function and thus increases the drug concentration in the brain. Although the efficacy of novel carrier system depends upon various physiological factors like active efflux transport, protein corona of the brain, stability, and toxicity of the nanocarrier, physicochemical properties, patient-related factors and many more. Hence, to develop a promising carrier system, it is essential to understand the physiology of the brain and BBB and also the other associated factors. Along with this, some alternative route like direct nose-to-brain drug delivery can also offer a better means to access the brain without exposure of the BBB. In this review, we have discussed the role of various physiological barriers including the BBB and blood-cerebrospinal fluid barrier (BCSFB) on the drug therapy and the mechanism of drug transport across the BBB. Further, we discussed different novel strategies for brain targeting of drug including, polymeric nanoparticles, lipidic nanoparticles, inorganic nanoparticles, liposomes, nanogels, nanoemulsions, dendrimers, quantum dots, etc. along with the intranasal drug delivery to the brain. We have also illustrated various factors affecting the drug targeting efficiency of the developed novel carrier system.

sections.text:
Receptor-mediated transcytosis has emerged as one of the most frequently employed strategies to enhance nanoparticle transport across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). This approach leverages specific receptors expressed on brain endothelial cells to facilitate the selective uptake and transport of functionalized nanoparticles <Paper corpusId="174798792" paperTitle="(Khongkow et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. The process typically involves the attachment of targeting ligands to nanoparticle surfaces that can bind to specific receptors on the BBB, triggering internalization and subsequent transcytosis into the brain parenchyma <Paper corpusId="56086575" paperTitle="(Vieira et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

Transferrin receptor (TfR) targeting represents one of the most well-established approaches. Gold nanoparticles tagged with transferrin or antibodies against transferrin receptor have successfully achieved brain internalization through a TfR-mediated and clathrin-dependent process <Paper corpusId="174798792" paperTitle="(Khongkow et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="21284359" paperTitle="(Cabezon et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. Recent studies have demonstrated that gold nanoparticles functionalized with transferrin show remarkable penetration into the brain by employing the receptor transcytosis pathway <Paper corpusId="271685623" paperTitle="(Zeynalzadeh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="227236300" paperTitle="(Zou et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Interestingly, gold nanoparticles with a cleavable acid linkage and transferrin coating showed enhanced brain accumulation compared to their non-cleavable counterparts, suggesting that controlled release mechanisms can further improve delivery efficiency <Paper corpusId="271685623" paperTitle="(Zeynalzadeh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) functionalization offers another effective approach for BBB penetration. ApoE-functionalized polymeric nanoparticles can transport various drugs across the BBB via low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptor-mediated transcytosis <Paper corpusId="225464702" paperTitle="(Hartl et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. While surfactant coatings like polysorbate 80 can facilitate ApoE adsorption onto nanoparticles, direct coating with ApoE without a surfactant anchor or covalent coupling of ApoE to nanoparticle surfaces has shown significantly improved brain uptake <Paper corpusId="225464702" paperTitle="(Hartl et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

Lactoferrin (Lf) has also gained attention as an effective targeting ligand due to the overexpression of lactoferrin receptors on both brain endothelial cells and certain brain tumor cells. Lactoferrin-modified nanoparticles have demonstrated enhanced brain targeting capabilities <Paper corpusId="271654496" paperTitle="(Budiman et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. In a notable study, dual-modified liposomes using lactoferrin and musk effectively crossed the BBB and enhanced the brain-targeting efficacy of docetaxel for glioma treatment <Paper corpusId="276645755" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="251514060" paperTitle="(Qi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

Angiopep-2 (Ang-2) represents another promising targeting ligand. In a microfluidic BBB model, liposomes functionalized with Ang-2 showed significantly higher binding to the apical surface of brain endothelial cells compared to non-functionalized controls. Under flow conditions, Ang-2 conjugation enhanced the nanoparticles' ability to penetrate the endothelial monolayer without affecting barrier function <Paper corpusId="235763032" paperTitle="(Kang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Novel brain-targeting ligands continue to emerge. For instance, T807, when used to functionalize human serum albumin nanoparticles coated with erythrocyte membranes, demonstrated enhanced transport ability across the BBB <Paper corpusId="220328755" paperTitle="(Gao et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Similarly, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) functionalized with various ligands have shown promise in targeting specific receptors on the BBB, improving their penetration and drug delivery capabilities <Paper corpusId="272017765" paperTitle="(Nabipour et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent research has demonstrated that combining multiple targeting ligands can further enhance BBB penetration. One study revealed that nanoparticles labeled with three different ligands targeting multiple transporters of brain endothelial cells promoted improved transfer and delivery of molecules across the BBB <Paper corpusId="245622624" paperTitle="(Veszelka et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. These multi-targeted approaches appear to work by elevating plasma membrane fluidity, suggesting a mechanism involving fusion of nanovesicles with endothelial cell membranes <Paper corpusId="245622624" paperTitle="(Veszelka et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The zeta potential of ligand-functionalized nanoparticles also plays a critical role in their interaction with the BBB. A moderately positive charge can enhance electrostatic interactions with negatively charged endothelial cells, further facilitating BBB penetration beyond the specific receptor-ligand interactions <Paper corpusId="275316417" paperTitle="(Musielak et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. This suggests that optimizing both specific targeting and surface charge characteristics can maximize BBB penetration efficiency.

paper.title: Trafficking of Gold Nanoparticles Coated with the 8D3 Anti-Transferrin Receptor Antibody at the Mouse Blood-Brain Barrier.

snippets: Receptor-mediated transcytosis has been widely studied as a possible strategy to transport neurotherapeutics across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Monoclonal antibodies directed against the transferrin receptor (TfR) have been proposed as potential carrier candidates. A better understanding of the mechanisms involved in their cellular uptake and intracellular trafficking is required and could critically contribute to the improvement of delivery methods. Accordingly, we studied here the trafficking of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) coated with the 8D3 anti-transferrin receptor antibody at the mouse BBB. 8D3-AuNPs were intravenously administered to mice and allowed to recirculate for a range of times, from 10 min to 24 h, before brain extraction and analysis by transmission electron microscope techniques. Our results indicated a TfR-mediated and clathrin-dependent internalization process by which 8D3-AuNPs internalize individually in vesicles. These vesicles then follow at least two different routes. On one hand, most vesicles enter intracellular processes of vesicular fusion and rearrangement in which the AuNPs end up accumulating in late endosomes, multivesicular bodies or lysosomes, which present a high AuNP content. On the other hand, a small percentage of the vesicles follow a different route in which they fuse with the abluminal membrane and open to the basal membrane. In these cases, the 8D3-AuNPs remain attached to the abluminal membrane, which suggests an endosomal escape, but not dissociation from TfR. Altogether, although receptor-mediated transport continues to be one of the most promising strategies to overcome the BBB, different optimization approaches need to be developed for efficient drug delivery.

paper.title: Tailored Mesoporous Inorganic Biomaterials: Assembly, Functionalization, and Drug Delivery Engineering

snippets: Infectious or immune diseases have caused serious threat to human health due to their complexity and specificity, and emerging drug delivery systems (DDSs) have evolved into the most promising therapeutic strategy for drug‐targeted therapy. Various mesoporous biomaterials are exploited and applied as efficient nanocarriers to loading drugs by virtue of their large surface area, high porosity, and prominent biocompatibility. Nanosized mesoporous nanocarriers show great potential in biomedical research, and it has become the research hotspot in the interdisciplinary field. Herein, recent progress and assembly mechanisms on mesoporous inorganic biomaterials (e.g., silica, carbon, metal oxide) are summarized systematically, and typical functionalization methods (i.e., hybridization, polymerization, and doping) for nanocarriers are also discussed in depth. Particularly, structure–activity relationship and the effect of physicochemical parameters of mesoporous biomaterials, including morphologies (e.g., hollow, core–shell), pore textures (e.g., pore size, pore volume), and surface features (e.g., roughness and hydrophilic/hydrophobic) in DDS application are overviewed and elucidated in detail. As one of the important development directions, advanced stimuli‐responsive DDSs (e.g., pH, temperature, redox, ultrasound, light, magnetic field) are highlighted. Finally, the prospect of mesoporous biomaterials in disease therapeutics is stated, and it will open a new spring for the development of mesoporous nanocarriers.

sections.text:
The surface charge or zeta potential of nanoparticles represents a crucial parameter that significantly influences their ability to traverse the blood-brain barrier (BBB). The BBB itself carries a negative charge, creating opportunities for ionic interactions with appropriately charged nanoparticles <Paper corpusId="214787055" paperTitle="(Saint-Pol et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Researchers have demonstrated that altering nanoparticle surface charges can enhance interactions with the BBB, creating an electrostatic "pull" toward the barrier that facilitates drug delivery <Paper corpusId="199545358" paperTitle="(Tiwari et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>.

Multiple studies indicate that moderately positive surface charges are particularly effective for BBB penetration. Gao et al. demonstrated efficient drug delivery across the BBB using positively charged vehicles with zeta potentials above 15 mV <Paper corpusId="244168314" paperTitle="(Daou et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="5413478" paperTitle="(Gao et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This positive charge enhances electrostatic interactions with the negatively charged endothelial cells of the BBB, facilitating penetration through mechanisms such as adsorptive endocytosis <Paper corpusId="275316417" paperTitle="(Musielak et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

However, the relationship between surface charge and BBB penetration requires careful optimization. While positive charges enhance BBB interactions, excessive positive charges may cause toxicity to the barrier <Paper corpusId="244168314" paperTitle="(Daou et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Current research suggests that an ideal surface charge for effective brain drug delivery is either positive or neutral, allowing nanoparticles to interact favorably with the BBB and cellular receptors without causing damage <Paper corpusId="268823870" paperTitle="(Khotimah et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The charge-dependent behavior of nanoparticles has been demonstrated in various experimental models. A recent study with mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) found that strongly positively charged particles modified with trimethylammonium (TA) effectively crossed the chick embryo BBB, while polyethylenimine (PEI)-modified particles with different charge characteristics did not <Paper corpusId="278364101" paperTitle="(Lin et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. Similarly, Hanada et al. showed that amino-functionalized quantum dots with positive surface charges passed through an in vitro BBB model more effectively than carboxyl- or PEGylated variants <Paper corpusId="244168314" paperTitle="(Daou et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="18465650" paperTitle="(Hanada et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

For negatively charged nanoparticles, the relationship between surface charge and diffusion in brain tissue shows interesting trends. Yuan et al. found that when the zeta potential is less negative than -10 mV, nanoparticles show diffusion coefficients in white matter similar to those in interstitial fluid, suggesting minimal hindrance to movement <Paper corpusId="268823870" paperTitle="(Khotimah et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="247599307" paperTitle="(Yuan et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>.

It's worth noting that surface charge modifications often work synergistically with other surface functionalization strategies. When proper surface functionalization is implemented, some studies suggest that the effect of size variations (from 5 to 400 nm) becomes less significant <Paper corpusId="245712356" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This indicates that charge optimization should be considered alongside other modifications such as targeting ligand attachment and stealth coatings to achieve maximum BBB penetration efficiency <Paper corpusId="268823870" paperTitle="(Khotimah et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="231898980" paperTitle="(Wiwatchaitawee et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

snippets: The extremely low permeability of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) poses the greatest impediment in the treatment of central nervous system (CNS) diseases. Recent work indicated that BBB permeability can be up-regulated by activating A2A adenosine receptor (AR), which temporarily increases intercellular spaces between the brain capillary endothelial cells. However, due to transient circulation lifetime of adenosine-based agonists, their capability to enhance brain delivery of drugs, especially macromolecular drugs, is limited. In this work, a series of nanoagonists (NAs) were developed by labeling different copies of A2A AR activating ligands on dendrimers. In vitro transendothelial electrical resistance measurements demonstrated that the NAs increased permeability of the endothelial cell monolayer by compromising the tightness of tight junctions, the key structure that restricts the entry of blood-borne molecules into the brain. In vivo imaging studies indicated the remarkably up-regulated brain uptake of a macromolecular model drug (45 kDa) after intravenous injection of NAs. paper.title: Enhancement of Therapies for Glioblastoma (GBM) Using Nanoparticle-based Delivery Systems

snippets: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is the most aggressive type of malignant brain tumor. Current FDA-approved treatments include surgical resection, radiation, and chemotherapy, while hyperthermia, immunotherapy, and most relevantly, nanoparticle (NP)-mediated delivery systems or combinations thereof have shown promise in preclinical studies. Drug-carrying NPs are a promising approach to brain delivery as a result of their potential to facilitate the crossing of the blood–brain barrier (BBB) via two main types of transcytosis mechanisms: adsorptive-mediated transcytosis (AMT) and receptor-mediated transcytosis (RMT). Their ability to accumulate in the brain can thus provide local sustained release of tumoricidal drugs at or near the site of GBM tumors. NP-based drug delivery has the potential to significantly reduce drug-related toxicity, increase specificity, and consequently improve the lifespan and quality of life of patients with GBM. Due to significant advances in the understanding of the molecular etiology and pathology of GBM, the efficacy of drugs loaded into vectors targeting this disease has increased in both preclinical and clinical settings. Multitargeting NPs, such as those incorporating multiple specific targeting ligands, are an innovative technology that can lead to decreased off-target effects while simultaneously having increased accumulation and action specifically at the tumor site. Targeting ligands can include antibodies, or fragments thereof, and peptides or small molecules, which can result in a more controlled drug delivery system compared to conventional drug treatments. This review focuses on GBM treatment strategies, summarizing current options and providing a detailed account of preclinical findings with prospective NP-based approaches aimed at improving tumor targeting and enhancing therapeutic outcomes for GBM patients.

sections.text:
Cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) represent a powerful class of surface modifications that can significantly enhance nanoparticle transport across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). These peptides are particularly effective due to their small size and positive charge characteristics, which make them highly favorable for transportation across the BBB <Paper corpusId="250336023" paperTitle="(Sharma et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. The positive charge of CPPs facilitates interaction with the negatively charged cell membranes of the BBB, promoting cellular uptake through various mechanisms.

Among the various CPPs, the HIV-1 trans-activating transcriptor (TAT) peptide has emerged as one of the most extensively studied for BBB applications. Nanoparticles modified with TAT have demonstrated remarkable ability to penetrate the BBB and accumulate in brain tissue. This effect is further enhanced when TAT modification is combined with polyethylene glycol (PEG) coating, creating a dual-modified nanoparticle system that shows higher BBB penetration and improved brain accumulation <Paper corpusId="21892073" paperTitle="(Parodi et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. The synergistic effect of these modifications—with TAT providing the cell-penetrating capability and PEG increasing circulation time—creates nanoparticles with optimized properties for brain drug delivery.

Research has shown that TAT-modified nanoparticles can be particularly useful for treating severe brain conditions such as brain tumors. While TAT modification alone does not provide specific targeting to nervous tissue, these particles can effectively accumulate in abnormal tumor vasculature, making them valuable for brain cancer therapy <Paper corpusId="21892073" paperTitle="(Parodi et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach leverages the enhanced permeability and retention effect commonly observed in tumor tissues.

Advanced approaches have been developed to further enhance the BBB-crossing capabilities of CPP-modified nanoparticles. For instance, Wang and colleagues demonstrated that conjugating TAT peptides to protein-based nanoparticles encapsulated with the zwitterionic polymer PMPC created a delivery platform with exceptional properties for CNS applications. This dual-modified system showed strong resistance to nonspecific adsorption (due to the PMPC coating), resulting in extended circulation lifetime, enhanced BBB permeability, and longer retention time inside the brain in mouse models <Paper corpusId="99491642" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

The versatility of CPPs extends beyond traditional nanoparticle formulations. Recent developments have explored the use of CPPs conjugated to nanoparticles carrying messenger RNA (mRNA), significantly improving their delivery efficiency to brain tissues <Paper corpusId="272783721" paperTitle="(Strika et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="9416016" paperTitle="(Fan et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach shows particular promise for gene therapy applications targeting neurological disorders.

When considering the broader landscape of brain-targeting modifications, CPPs can be integrated with other targeting strategies such as transferrin and lactoferrin conjugation. These protein-based modifications target specific receptors abundantly expressed in the brain region, creating multi-functional nanoparticles with enhanced BBB penetration capabilities <Paper corpusId="250336023" paperTitle="(Sharma et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This combinatorial approach allows researchers to leverage multiple transport mechanisms simultaneously, potentially overcoming the limitations of single-modification strategies.

paper.title: Submicron-Bubble-Enhanced Focused Ultrasound for Blood–Brain Barrier Disruption and Improved CNS Drug Delivery

snippets: The use of focused ultrasound (FUS) with microbubbles has been proven to induce transient blood–brain barrier opening (BBB-opening). However, FUS-induced inertial cavitation of microbubbles can also result in erythrocyte extravasations. Here we investigated whether induction of submicron bubbles to oscillate at their resonant frequency would reduce inertial cavitation during BBB-opening and thereby eliminate erythrocyte extravasations in a rat brain model. FUS was delivered with acoustic pressures of 0.1–4.5 MPa using either in-house manufactured submicron bubbles or standard SonoVue microbubbles. Wideband and subharmonic emissions from bubbles were used to quantify inertial and stable cavitation, respectively. Erythrocyte extravasations were evaluated by in vivo post-treatment magnetic resonance susceptibility-weighted imaging, and finally by histological confirmation. We found that excitation of submicron bubbles with resonant frequency-matched FUS (10 MHz) can greatly limit inertial cavitation while enhancing stable cavitation. The BBB-opening was mainly caused by stable cavitation, whereas the erythrocyte extravasation was closely correlated with inertial cavitation. Our technique allows extensive reduction of inertial cavitation to induce safe BBB-opening. Furthermore, the safety issue of BBB-opening was not compromised by prolonging FUS exposure time, and the local drug concentrations in the brain tissues were significantly improved to 60 times (BCNU; 18.6 µg versus 0.3 µg) by using chemotherapeutic agent-loaded submicron bubbles with FUS. This study provides important information towards the goal of successfully translating FUS brain drug delivery into clinical use.

sections.text:
While polymer coatings, surfactants, targeting ligands, and charge modifications represent mainstream approaches to enhancing nanoparticle transport across the blood-brain barrier (BBB), researchers continue to develop more specialized and innovative surface modifications to address specific delivery challenges. These specialized approaches often incorporate advanced materials science concepts and responsive elements to further improve BBB penetration.

Inorganic nanomaterial-based modifications offer unique advantages for BBB crossing. Magnetic nanoparticles (Fe₃O₄), when coated with carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), gain improved biocompatibility, stability, and functionalization sites for drug loading, enhancing their ability to cross the BBB for targeted delivery <Paper corpusId="271685623" paperTitle="(Zeynalzadeh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These magnetic nanoparticles can be externally guided using magnetic fields to improve BBB penetration and achieve controlled release of therapeutic agents <Paper corpusId="271685623" paperTitle="(Zeynalzadeh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="233670069" paperTitle="(Choi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) represent another promising platform for specialized surface modifications. When surface-modified with PEG, AuNPs demonstrate enhanced drug delivery capabilities across the BBB <Paper corpusId="271685623" paperTitle="(Zeynalzadeh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="225046679" paperTitle="(Sokolova et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. Ultrasmall gold nanoparticles (core diameter 2 nm) have shown remarkable ability to penetrate BBB models, even when the dissolved fluorescent dye alone cannot cross <Paper corpusId="225046679" paperTitle="(Sokolova et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This suggests that the unique physicochemical properties of these nanoparticles, beyond just their surface modifications, play a critical role in BBB penetration.

Stimuli-responsive surface modifications represent an emerging specialized approach. These "smart" coatings respond to specific triggers such as pH changes, temperature variations, redox conditions, ultrasound, light, or magnetic fields <Paper corpusId="271685623" paperTitle="(Zeynalzadeh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="227236300" paperTitle="(Zou et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. For instance, near-infrared (NIR) responsive nanoparticles offer a non-invasive method to trigger drug release across the BBB on demand <Paper corpusId="271685623" paperTitle="(Zeynalzadeh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="233670069" paperTitle="(Choi et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Novel hybrid systems have been developed that combine multiple materials to create specialized surface modifications. A drug-carrying nanoparticle system based on pterostilbene and black phosphorus, modified with polydopamine (creating the BP-Pte@PDA delivery system), specifically degrades and releases drugs in ischemic brain regions <Paper corpusId="276645755" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>. This targeted release mechanism significantly reduces brain infarction, improves neurological function, and inhibits apoptosis in stroke models.

The importance of multi-component surface modifications is further highlighted in specialized targeting systems. Dual-modified liposomes using both lactoferrin and musk have demonstrated enhanced BBB crossing ability and improved brain-targeting efficacy for drugs like docetaxel in glioma treatment <Paper corpusId="276645755" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="251514060" paperTitle="(Qi et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. This "guided" approach with musk significantly enhances the brain-targeting capabilities of the already effective lactoferrin modification.

Various other specialized coatings have been developed to address specific limitations of nanoparticle delivery systems. These include small molecule coatings, lipid coatings, and lipopolymer coatings, each designed to facilitate iron nanoparticle transport across the BBB for both diagnostic and therapeutic applications <Paper corpusId="220853113" paperTitle="(Wu et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The versatility of nanoparticle platforms allows for optimization through modifications of size, shape, and surface properties to improve interaction and diffusion through cells and tissues <Paper corpusId="260752373" paperTitle="(Mineiro et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. This optimization potential makes nanotechnology-based systems including liposomes, polymeric nanoparticles, and solid lipid nanoparticles particularly valuable for enhancing drug bioavailability and achieving controlled release across the BBB <Paper corpusId="278625786" paperTitle="(Ali et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

Advanced strategies in nanocarrier design also include specialized surface modifications with substrates of BBB-specific transport proteins and efflux transporter inhibitors <Paper corpusId="271333447" paperTitle="(Ping et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These approaches enhance transcytosis-mediated drug penetration across the BBB, optimizing drug locational specificity and bioavailability within the brain.

paper.title: Transport of ultrasmall gold nanoparticles (2 nm) across the blood–brain barrier in a six-cell brain spheroid model

snippets: The blood–brain barrier (BBB) is an efficient barrier for molecules and drugs. Multicellular 3D spheroids display reproducible BBB features and functions. The spheroids used here were composed of six brain cell types: Astrocytes, pericytes, endothelial cells, microglia cells, oligodendrocytes, and neurons. They form an in vitro BBB that regulates the transport of compounds into the spheroid. The penetration of fluorescent ultrasmall gold nanoparticles (core diameter 2 nm; hydrodynamic diameter 3–4 nm) across the BBB was studied as a function of time by confocal laser scanning microscopy, with the dissolved fluorescent dye (FAM-alkyne) as a control. The nanoparticles readily entered the interior of the spheroid, whereas the dissolved dye alone did not penetrate the BBB. We present a model that is based on a time-dependent opening of the BBB for nanoparticles, followed by a rapid diffusion into the center of the spheroid. After the spheroids underwent hypoxia (0.1% O2; 24 h), the BBB was more permeable, permitting the uptake of more nanoparticles and also of dissolved dye molecules. Together with our previous observations that such nanoparticles can easily enter cells and even the cell nucleus, these data provide evidence that ultrasmall nanoparticle can cross the blood brain barrier.

paper.title: Tailored Mesoporous Inorganic Biomaterials: Assembly, Functionalization, and Drug Delivery Engineering

snippets: Infectious or immune diseases have caused serious threat to human health due to their complexity and specificity, and emerging drug delivery systems (DDSs) have evolved into the most promising therapeutic strategy for drug‐targeted therapy. Various mesoporous biomaterials are exploited and applied as efficient nanocarriers to loading drugs by virtue of their large surface area, high porosity, and prominent biocompatibility. Nanosized mesoporous nanocarriers show great potential in biomedical research, and it has become the research hotspot in the interdisciplinary field. Herein, recent progress and assembly mechanisms on mesoporous inorganic biomaterials (e.g., silica, carbon, metal oxide) are summarized systematically, and typical functionalization methods (i.e., hybridization, polymerization, and doping) for nanocarriers are also discussed in depth. Particularly, structure–activity relationship and the effect of physicochemical parameters of mesoporous biomaterials, including morphologies (e.g., hollow, core–shell), pore textures (e.g., pore size, pore volume), and surface features (e.g., roughness and hydrophilic/hydrophobic) in DDS application are overviewed and elucidated in detail. As one of the important development directions, advanced stimuli‐responsive DDSs (e.g., pH, temperature, redox, ultrasound, light, magnetic field) are highlighted. Finally, the prospect of mesoporous biomaterials in disease therapeutics is stated, and it will open a new spring for the development of mesoporous nanocarriers.

sections.title: Mechanisms of Enhanced BBB Crossing
sections.tldr: Nanoparticles traverse the blood-brain barrier through several key mechanisms including receptor-mediated transcytosis, adsorptive-mediated transcytosis, membrane fusion, and inhibition of efflux transporters. sections.text:
Understanding the mechanisms by which surface-modified nanoparticles cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is essential for designing effective drug delivery systems. Among these mechanisms, receptor-mediated transcytosis represents one of the most frequently employed and successful strategies. This process involves nanoparticles binding to specific receptors on brain endothelial cells, triggering internalization through receptor-mediated vesicular fusion and rearrangement <Paper corpusId="174798792" paperTitle="(Khongkow et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="20863171" paperTitle="(Wilhelm et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. Gold nanoparticles tagged with transferrin or antibodies against transferrin receptors utilize this pathway to achieve brain internalization through a TfR-mediated and clathrin-dependent process <Paper corpusId="174798792" paperTitle="(Khongkow et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="21284359" paperTitle="(Cabezon et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>.

Apolipoprotein-mediated transport represents another crucial mechanism for BBB penetration. Surfactant coatings such as polysorbate 80 and poloxamer 188 facilitate this process by enabling the adsorption of plasma apolipoproteins, particularly apolipoprotein E (ApoE), onto the nanoparticle surface. This modification essentially mimics low-density lipoproteins (LDL), allowing recognition by LDL receptors expressed on brain endothelial cells and subsequent transport via receptor-mediated endocytosis <Paper corpusId="225464702" paperTitle="(Hartl et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="268928188" paperTitle="(Narsinh et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Studies have shown that direct coating with ApoE without a surfactant anchor or covalent coupling of ApoE to nanoparticles leads to significantly improved brain uptake compared to surfactant-mediated approaches <Paper corpusId="225464702" paperTitle="(Hartl et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

Surface modifications can also enhance BBB penetration by altering membrane interactions. Targeted nanoparticles have been shown to elevate plasma membrane fluidity, indicating the fusion of nanovesicles with endothelial cell membranes <Paper corpusId="245622624" paperTitle="(Veszelka et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. This mechanism appears particularly effective when multiple targeting ligands are employed simultaneously. Research has demonstrated that nanoparticles labeled with three different ligands targeting multiple transporters of brain endothelial cells promote improved transfer and delivery of molecules across the BBB <Paper corpusId="245622624" paperTitle="(Veszelka et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Inhibition of efflux transporters represents another significant mechanism for enhanced BBB penetration. Surfactants such as polysorbate 80 and PEG-D-α-tocopheryl can enhance BBB permeation by inhibiting the efflux action of P-glycoprotein and solubilizing cell membrane lipids of brain endothelial cells <Paper corpusId="10445103" paperTitle="(Kanwar et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. This dual action—inhibiting efflux pumps while facilitating membrane permeation—significantly improves the ability of nanoparticles to deliver their therapeutic payload across the BBB.

The creation of concentration gradients represents a less-studied but potentially important mechanism. Some researchers have suggested that surfactant coatings help bind nanoparticles to capillary linings, creating concentration gradients that facilitate diffusion <Paper corpusId="5143982" paperTitle="(Parratt et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="30272015" paperTitle="(Schroeder et al., 1998)" isShortName></Paper>. Additionally, these coatings may purposefully induce phagocytosis processes in epithelial cells, providing another route for BBB penetration <Paper corpusId="5143982" paperTitle="(Parratt et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

Surface charge modifications also significantly impact BBB penetration mechanisms. For instance, cationized bovine serum albumin nanoparticles have demonstrated an eightfold increase in BBB permeability compared to their non-cationized counterparts <Paper corpusId="269512854" paperTitle="(Liu et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. This enhancement likely occurs through adsorptive-mediated transcytosis, where positively charged nanoparticles interact with the negatively charged cell membrane, facilitating internalization.

The most effective surface modifications typically engage multiple mechanisms simultaneously. For example, polysorbate 80-coated polybutylcyanoacrylate nanoparticles not only facilitate apolipoprotein adsorption for receptor-mediated transcytosis but also inhibit P-glycoprotein efflux and potentially increase membrane fluidity <Paper corpusId="10445103" paperTitle="(Kanwar et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. snippets: Another major challenge is the blood brain barrier, which is formed by the endothelial cells that line cerebral microvessels if the target site is located in the central nervous system (CNS). Unlike blood capillaries elsewhere in the body, the structure of the BBB is characterized by the tight-junctions that are tightly resistant to the exchange of substances between the blood and the nervous tissue (Wilhelm et al., 2014)

In order to overcome this challenge, several strategies have been developed to enhance penetration of drugs into the brain. Of these, the most frequently used is receptor-mediated transcytosis. Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) tagged with transferrin or L-DOPA is one of successful examples for brain targeting. The study of Cabezon, I. et al., 2015 reported that the physical modification of AuNPs with an external antibody against transferrin receptor has successfully achieved for brain internalization using ligand-receptor mediated vesicular fusion and rearrangement within few hours after exposure 37. Similary, our results clearly demonstrate that the transport across BBB of AuNPs after genetically surface modification with RVG-exosome could be enhanced compared to AuNPs coated with unmodified exosomes.

paper.title: In vitro models of the blood-brain barrier for the study of drug delivery to the brain.

snippets: The most important obstacle to the drug delivery into the brain is the presence of the blood-brain barrier, which limits the traffic of substances between the blood and the nervous tissue. Therefore, adequate in vitro models need to be developed in order to characterize the penetration properties of drug candidates into the central nervous system. This review article summarizes the presently used and the most promising in vitro BBB models based on the culture of brain endothelial cells. Robust models can be obtained using primary porcine brain endothelial cells and rodent coculture models, which have low paracellular permeability and express functional efflux transporters, showing good correlation of drug penetration data with in vivo results. Models mimicking the in vivo anatomophysiological complexity of the BBB are also available, including triple coculture (culture of brain endothelial cells in the presence of pericytes and astrocytes), dynamic, and microfluidic models; however, these are not suitable for rapid, high throughput studies. Potent human cell lines would be needed for easily available and reproducible models which avoid interspecies differences.

paper.title: Trafficking of Gold Nanoparticles Coated with the 8D3 Anti-Transferrin Receptor Antibody at the Mouse Blood-Brain Barrier.

snippets: Receptor-mediated transcytosis has been widely studied as a possible strategy to transport neurotherapeutics across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Monoclonal antibodies directed against the transferrin receptor (TfR) have been proposed as potential carrier candidates. A better understanding of the mechanisms involved in their cellular uptake and intracellular trafficking is required and could critically contribute to the improvement of delivery methods. Accordingly, we studied here the trafficking of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) coated with the 8D3 anti-transferrin receptor antibody at the mouse BBB. 8D3-AuNPs were intravenously administered to mice and allowed to recirculate for a range of times, from 10 min to 24 h, before brain extraction and analysis by transmission electron microscope techniques. Our results indicated a TfR-mediated and clathrin-dependent internalization process by which 8D3-AuNPs internalize individually in vesicles. These vesicles then follow at least two different routes. On one hand, most vesicles enter intracellular processes of vesicular fusion and rearrangement in which the AuNPs end up accumulating in late endosomes, multivesicular bodies or lysosomes, which present a high AuNP content. On the other hand, a small percentage of the vesicles follow a different route in which they fuse with the abluminal membrane and open to the basal membrane. In these cases, the 8D3-AuNPs remain attached to the abluminal membrane, which suggests an endosomal escape, but not dissociation from TfR. Altogether, although receptor-mediated transport continues to be one of the most promising strategies to overcome the BBB, different optimization approaches need to be developed for efficient drug delivery.
